skills.name: Represent positive unit fractions on a number line
Represent positive non-unit fractions on a number line

explanations.A: Not quite - there are 4 sections on the diagram, but can you see that 1 is marked after 3 sections? That means the scale is going up in thirds. So what fraction is marked by the star?
explanations.B: The number 1 is marked after 3 sections of the scale, so the scale must be counting in thirds (1/3, 2/3, 3/3 =1). The star is marked after 1 section, so this is 1/3.
explanations.C: Not quite - there are 5 lines on the scale, but we count the gaps/jumps, not the lines. How many jumps is it from 0 to 1 on the scale?
explanations.D: This scale is not counting in 1s. Can you see that 1 is marked after 3 sections? That means the scale is going up in thirds. So what fraction is marked by the star?

explanations.A: The number 1 is marked after 4 sections of the scale, so the scale must be counting in quarters (1/4, 2/4, 3/4, 4/4 = 1). The star is marked after 1 section, so this is 1/4.
explanations.B: Not quite - there are 5 lines on the scale from 0 to 1, but we count the gaps/jumps, not the lines. How many jumps is it from 0 to 1 on the scale?
explanations.C: Not quite - there are 5 sections on the diagram, but can you see that 1 is marked after 4 sections? That means the scale is going up in quarters. So what fraction is marked by the star?
explanations.D: This scale is not counting in 1s. Can you see that 1 is marked after 4 sections? That means the scale is going up in quarters. So what fraction is marked by the star?

explanations.A: Not quite - make sure you are counting jumps along the scale, not lines.
explanations.B: 1 is marked after 5 sections, so each section is 1/5. B is marked on the scale after 2 sections, so B is at 2/5.
explanations.C: Not quite - remember 1 is the same as 5/5, so if we start from 1 we count back 4/5, 3/5, 2/5.
explanations.D: Not quite - each section of the scale is 1/5, so can you start at 0 and count up 2/5?

explanations.A: Not quite - each section of the scale is 1/6, so can you start at 0 and count up to 5/6?
explanations.B: Not quite - each section of the scale is 1/6, so can you start at 0 and count up to 5/6? Also, remember that we count the gaps/jumps, not the lines.
explanations.C: Not quite - make sure you are counting jumps along the scale, not lines.
explanations.D: 1 is marked after 6 sections, so each section is 1/6. D is marked on the scale after 5 sections, so D is at 5/6.

explanations.A: The top scale has 4 sections between 0 and 1, so each section is 1/4. A is marked after 1 section, so it is at 1/4. The bottom scale has 3 sections, so C is at 1/3 not 1/4.
explanations.B: Not quite - make sure you are counting jumps along the scale and not lines. The top scale is split into 4 jumps, so how many jumps would we go along for 1/4?
explanations.C: Not quite - make sure you are counting jumps along the scale and not lines. The bottom scale is split into 3 jumps, so each jump is 1/3. The top scale is split into 4 jumps, so how many jumps would we go along for 1/4?
explanations.D: Not quite - the bottom scale is split into 3 jumps, so each jump is 1/3.

explanations.A: Not quite - make sure you are counting jumps along the scale and not lines. The bottom scale is split into 3 jumps, so how many jumps would we go along for 1/3?
explanations.B: 1 means "1 whole", both scales start at 0 and end at 1. Start by finding which scale is divided into thirds (3 jumps).
explanations.C: The bottom scale has 3 sections between 0 and 1, so each section is 1/3. C is marked after 1 section, so it is at 1/3. The top scale has 2 sections, so A is at 1/2 and B is at 1.
explanations.D: Not quite - the top scale is split into 2 jumps, so each jump is 1/2.

explanations.A: 5/8 means 5 out of 8 equal parts. Which scale is split into 8 equal parts?
explanations.B: Not quite - make sure you are counting jumps along the scale and not lines. The bottom scale is split into 8 jumps, so how many jumps would we go along for 5/8?
explanations.C: The bottom scale is split into 8 equal parts, so each jump is 1/8. C is marked after 5 jumps, so C is at 5/8.
explanations.D: Not quite - remember 1 is the same as 8/8, so if we are counting back from 1 we would count 7/8, 6/8, 5/8.

explanations.A: Not quite - remember 1 is the same as 4/4, so if we are counting back from 1 we would count 3/4, 2/4, 1/4, 0.
explanations.B: Not quite - make sure you are counting jumps along the scale and not lines. The black lines on both scales divide them into 4 equal jumps, so how many jumps would we go along for 3/4?
explanations.C: Not quite. You've counted 3 of the small jumps, but there are 8 small jumps between 0 and 1, so C is at 3/8. Just look at the black lines, they are dividing both lines into 4 equal jumps, so each of these jumps is 1/4.
explanations.D: The black lines on both scales divide them into 4 equal parts, so each jump is 1/4. D is marked after 3 of these jumps, so D is at 3/4.

explanations.A: Not quite, I think you just counted 5 lines. But to find where 9/5 is located we need to find the value of each jump. If it takes 10 jumps to get to 2 on the scale, how much is each jump worth? If we are starting at 0, how many jumps will be 9/5?
explanations.B: Not quite, maybe you are thinking of 5/9? If it takes 10 jumps to get to 2 on the scale, each jump must be 1/5. How many jumps will be 9/5?
explanations.C: Almost, but I think you have counted the start of the scale as 1/5. The start of the scale is 0, so the next mark on the scale will be 1/5, then 2/5...
explanations.D: It takes 10 jumps on the scale to get to 2, so each jump is 1/5. 9 jumps along the scale gets us to D so D is at 9/5.

explanations.A: Not quite, maybe you are thinking of 6/11? If it takes 12 jumps to get to 2 on the scale, each jump must be 1/6. Also, make sure you are counting jumps along the scale and not lines.
explanations.B: Not quite, maybe you are thinking of 6/11? If it takes 12 jumps to get to 2 on the scale, each jump must be 1/6.
explanations.C: Not quite, make sure you are counting jumps along the scale and not lines.
explanations.D: It takes 12 jumps on the scale to get to 2, so each jump is 1/6. 11 jumps along the scale gets us to D, so D is at 11/6.
